>From: Derek James <djames@...>
>
> > John Arrowwood wrote:
> >  I'm asking it not to identify features and classify them, I'm
> > >asking it to form a mathematical model, and query that model.  But 
>that's
> > >not what an ANN does, does it?
>
>Why not?
>
>Isn't there a theorem somewhere demonstrating that a multi-layer ANN
>can approximate any continuous function?
>

That's true, and that's part of the reason I haven't given up...

I made some tweaks to my NEAT implementation (trying to make sure every 
mutation produces a NEW topology rather than resurrecting a dead one) and 
introduced a bug in the process.  Namely, it couldn't split nodes any more.  
All topological variations had to come from permutations of adding and 
removing connections.  And all because of one little letter in the code.  
DOH!  But that is why after thousands of topologies I wasn't making any 
progress.  Still had no hidden nodes!

After identifying and correcting that bug, I've re-started the run.  I've 
got my fingers crossed.

>I'm pretty interested in how your project is going, since we might be
>considering using a neural network to perform some sort of
>pre-processing on our images before identification by the eye.

Keep in mind that my project seeks to do it dynamically.  That is, the 
output doesn't depend just on the pixel inputs, it also depends on the 
positional parameters.  The same pixel inputs with vastly different 
positional parameters yeilds a vastly different output.

Success in basic image enlargement is already proven.  I can point you to 
papers on the subject.  It has also been demonstrated for other kinds of 
image processing.  So unless you also intend to employ some kind of 
non-pixel inputs in your image processing, my project is (in its present 
form) irrelevant to you.  Heck, if I'd have been willing to settle for a 
fixed enlargement scale, I'd probably be done already.  :(

>Is anyone on the list familiar with binarization?  It's basically the
>process of converting all the greyscale values of a greyscale image to
>either black or white, in order to simplify, clarify, or sharpen an
>image for further processing.  It's used, for example, to distinguish
>foreground from background.
>
>This probably won't be much use for our current data set, but if we're
>processing more complicated images, especially those with low contrast
>or a lot of background noise, we may want to apply some sort of
>binarization technique before showing it to the ANN eye for
>identification.
>
>The simplest and crudest binarization function simply reads the value
>of each pixel, and if it's below a particular threshold value (e.g.
>177 out of 256 greyscale values), it sets the value to 0, and if it's
>above the threshold it sets it to 1.  More complicated functions take
>into consideration the contrast in a particular area and dynamically
>adjust the threshold accordingly.  For example, one technique uses a
>formula which calculates the threshold based on the mean pixel value
>and standard deviation for the 15x15 region around a given pixel.
>
>Such a function could be performed by a neural network, right?

Where your output is always in a fixed relationship to your inputs, yes.

>And such an approach is similar to what you're trying to achieve, isn't it?

Except for the positional parameters, yes.  It's those positional parameters 
that greatly complicates things.

-- John
